description: An examination of the various non-judicial and judicial processes and institutions used in settling disputes in public international law, including 'mixed' processes that avail dispute settlement between States and legal persons, the development of 'hybrid' mechanisms to address new and emerging types of dispute, UN Charter provisions discouraging resort to war by States and authorising the use of force by the UN to uphold the objectives and principles of the Charter, the laws and customs of war (international humanitarian law), the Responsibility to Protect, and peacekeeping.
restricted:
GCAppLaw; GDipAppLaw; MAppLaw; LLM; LLM(Adv); LLM(16), LLM(24); MICLaw(16), MIL and MIR/MIL.
Quota: minimum of 12 enrolments.
